dt: {bc}to combine or associate so that the separate constituents or the line of demarcation cannot be distinguished
{bc}to prepare by thoroughly intermingling different varieties or grades

pt: {sc}mix{/sc} {sc}mingle{/sc} {sc}commingle{/sc} {sc}blend{/sc} {sc}merge{/sc} {sc}coalesce{/sc} {sc}amalgamate{/sc} {sc}fuse{/sc} mean to combine into a more or less uniform whole. {sc}mix{/sc} may or may not imply loss of each element's identity.
{sc}mingle{/sc} usually suggests that the elements are still somewhat distinguishable or separately active.

pt.t: fear {it}mingled{/it} with anticipation in my mind

pt: {sc}commingle{/sc} implies a closer or more thorough mingling.

pt.t: a sense of duty {it}commingled{/it} with a fierce pride drove her

pt: {sc}blend{/sc} implies that the elements as such disappear in the resulting mixture.

pt.t: {it}blended{/it} several teas to create a balanced flavor

pt: {sc}merge{/sc} suggests a combining in which one or more elements are lost in the whole.

pt.t: in his mind reality and fantasy {it}merged{/it}

pt: {sc}coalesce{/sc} implies an affinity in the merging elements and usually a resulting organic unity.

pt.t: telling details that {it}coalesce{/it} into a striking portrait

pt: {sc}amalgamate{/sc} implies the forming of a close union without complete loss of individual identities.

pt.t: refugees who were readily {it}amalgamated{/it} into the community

pt: {sc}fuse{/sc} stresses oneness and indissolubility of the resulting product.

pt.t: a building in which modernism and classicism are {it}fused{/it}

et: Middle English, probably from Old Norse {it}blend-{/it}, present stem of {it}blanda{/it} to mix; akin to Old English {it}blandan{/it} to mix, Lithuanian {it}blandus{/it} impure, cloudy
shortdef: mix; especially : to combine or associate so that the separate constituents or the line of demarcation cannot be distinguished
to prepare by thoroughly intermingling different varieties or grades

dt: {bc}a family that includes children of a previous marriage of one spouse or both

shortdef: a family that includes children of a previous marriage of one spouse or both

dt: {bc}whiskey blended from two or more straight whiskeys or from whiskey and neutral spirits

shortdef: whiskey blended from two or more straight whiskeys or from whiskey and neutral spirits

dt.t: The fish settles on the sandy ocean bottom where it {it}blends in{/it} perfectly.

dt: {bc}to look like one belongs with a particular group

dt.t: She tried to {it}blend in{/it} by dressing like the other girls.
I've always found it difficult to {it}blend in with{/it} my peers.

dt: {bc}to add (something) to a mixture or substance and mix it thoroughly

dt.t: Mix the first three ingredients together, then {it}blend in{/it} the cream.

shortdef: to look like one belongs with a particular group —often + with
to add (something) to a mixture or substance and mix it thoroughly

dt: {bc}to gradually become the same as or part of (something)

dt.t: where the city {it}blends into{/it} the suburbs
The animal's dark fur enables it to {it}blend into{/it} the forest.
He tried to {it}blend into{/it} the crowd.
A good journalist can easily {it}blend into{/it} a community.

shortdef: to gradually become the same as or part of (something)
to look like one belongs in (something)
